Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with another message from Mia. We’d argued three times this week about money—her frustration simmering just beneath every word. As her boyfriend, I knew I should call her, try to smooth things over, listen to her worries, and show her I cared enough to work through this together. But the sawdust in my hair and the ache in my hands reminded me of the cabinetry project waiting for me at the site. The deadline was tight, and the electrician and plumber were both waiting for my framework before they could finish their parts. If I didn’t get back soon, the whole schedule would slip, and my boss would be on my case. I felt pulled in two directions—Mia needed me to be present and attentive, but my crew needed me to be reliable and focused. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role I could afford to let down.
